required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on April 13, 2016

clinical_study.brief_title: Comparison of Telavancin and Vancomycin for Hospital-acquired Pneumonia Due to Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus Aureus
clinical_study.official_title: A Phase 3, Randomized, Double-Blind, Parallel-Group, Multinational Trial of Intravenous Telavancin Versus Vancomycin for Treatment of Hospital-Acquired Pneumonia With a Focus on Patients With Infections Due to Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus Aureus

brief_summary.textblock: Study 0019 (NCT00124020) compares the safety and effectiveness of an investigational drug, telavancin, with vancomycin for the treatment of hospital-acquired pneumonia.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Safety/Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Double Blind (Subject, Caregiver, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor), Primary Purpose: Treatment

primary_outcome.time_frame: 7-14 days following end of antibiotic treatment
primary_outcome.description: Clinical Response: Categorical (Cured, Failed or Indeterminate) Failure - at least one of the following: Persistence or progression of signs and symptoms of pneumonia that still require antibiotic therapy Termination of study med due to "lack of efficacy" Death on or after Day 3 attributable to primary infection Cure: Signs and symptoms of pneumonia improved to the point that no further antibiotics for pneumonia were required, and baseline radiographic findings improved or did not progress. Indeterminate: Inability to determine outcome

intervention.description: Telavancin 10 mg/kg/day IV for up to 21 days
Vancomycin 1 Gm administered every 12 hrs IV for up to 21 days

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Clinical signs and symptoms consistent with pneumonia acquired after at least 48 hours of continuous stay in an inpatient acute or chronic care facility or acquired within 7 days after being discharged from a hospitalization of greater than or equal to 3 days duration.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Received more than 24 hours of potentially effective systemic (IV, IM or PO) antibiotic therapy for Gram-positive pneumonia immediately prior to randomization.

facility.name: Sheba Medical Center, Infectious Disease Unit

responsible_party.name_title: Steven L. Barriere, Pharm.D., Vice President, Clinical and Medical Affairs

participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: 14 patients (9 telavancin and 5 vancomycin) enrolled in the study but never started study treatment

group.title: Telavancin
group.description: Patients with Gram-positive hospital acquired pneumonia (HAP) (primarily due to MRSA) were randomized to receive telavancin 10 mg/kg IV every 24 hrs

group.title: Vancomycin
group.description: Patients with Gram-positive hospital acquired pneumonia (HAP)(primarily due to MRSA) were randomized to receive vancomycin 1 Gm IV every 12 hrs.

group.title: Telavancin
group.description: Patients with Gram-positive hospital acquired pneumonia (HAP) (primarily due to MRSA) were randomized to receive telavancin 10 mg/kg IV every 24 hrs

group.title: Vancomycin
group.description: Patients with Gram-positive hospital acquired pneumonia (HAP)(primarily due to MRSA) were randomized to receive vancomycin 1 Gm IV every 12 hrs.

outcome.title: Clinical Response
outcome.description: Clinical Response: Categorical (Cured, Failed or Indeterminate) Failure - at least one of the following: Persistence or progression of signs and symptoms of pneumonia that still require antibiotic therapy Termination of study med due to “lack of efficacy” Death on or after Day 3 attributable to primary infection Cure: Signs and symptoms of pneumonia improved to the point that no further antibiotics for pneumonia were required, and baseline radiographic findings improved or did not progress. Indeterminate: Inability to determine outcome
outcome.time_frame: 7-14 days following end of antibiotic treatment

group.title: Telavancin
group.description: Patients with Gram-positive hospital acquired pneumonia (HAP) (primarily due to MRSA) were randomized to receive telavancin 10 mg/kg IV every 24 hrs

group.title: Vancomycin
group.description: Patients with Gram-positive hospital acquired pneumonia (HAP)(primarily due to MRSA) were randomized to receive vancomycin 1 Gm IV every 12 hrs.

measure.title: Clinical Response
measure.description: Clinical Response: Categorical (Cured, Failed or Indeterminate) Failure - at least one of the following: Persistence or progression of signs and symptoms of pneumonia that still require antibiotic therapy Termination of study med due to “lack of efficacy” Death on or after Day 3 attributable to primary infection Cure: Signs and symptoms of pneumonia improved to the point that no further antibiotics for pneumonia were required, and baseline radiographic findings improved or did not progress. Indeterminate: Inability to determine outcome

analysis.non_inferiority_desc: Non-inferiority margin of 20% was specified based on historical regulatory precedent.

reported_events.desc: Two patients were randomized to vancomycin, yet were treated with telavancin. For analyses of efficacy, results were analyzed according to the treatment group assigned by randomization. For safety analyses, results were analyzed according to treatment received; 379 patients received telavancin and 378 patients received vancomycin.

group.title: Telavancin
group.description: Patients with Gram-positive hospital acquired pneumonia (HAP) (primarily due to MRSA) were randomized to receive telavancin 10 mg/kg IV every 24 hrs

group.title: Vancomycin
group.description: Patients with Gram-positive hospital acquired pneumonia (HAP)(primarily due to MRSA) were randomized to receive vancomycin 1 Gm IV every 12 hrs.

category.title: Neoplasms benign, malignant and unspecified (incl cysts and polyps)

event.sub_title: Small Cell Lung Cancer stage unspecified

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: The only disclosure restriction on the PI is that the sponsor can review results communications prior to public release and can embargo communications regarding trial results for a period that is less than or equal to 60 days. The sponsor cannot require changes to the communication and cannot extend the embargo.

point_of_contact.name_or_title: Steve Barriere, Pharm.D., Vice President, Clinical and Medical Affairs
